title: Vacant Periods During Extended Rental

scenario_info.name: Vacant Periods During Extended Rental
scenario_info.description: Michelle rents her main residence for 8 years with two vacant periods when tenants change. The vacant periods count towards the 6-year limit when the property is available for rent. Total rental period exceeds 6 years, resulting in partial exemption.

expected_result.notes: After 50% discount. Vacant periods while available for rent count towards 6-year limit.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule exceeded
Vacant periods while property available for rent count towards 6-year limit
Only genuinely taking property off rental market stops the clock
ITAA97 s118.192: First use to produce income rule
50% CGT discount applies to taxable portion
Rental period (9 years including vacant) exceeds 6 years by 3 years

property_history.description: First tenant moves in. Market value at first rental: $340,000
Tenant leaves. Property VACANT but still available for rent (counts toward 6-year limit)
Second tenant moves in after 3-month vacancy
Tenant leaves. Property VACANT but still available for rent (counts toward 6-year limit)
Third tenant moves in after 2-month vacancy

properties.notes: Partial exemption (66.69%). Total rental period including vacant periods: 9 years. Exceeds 6-year limit by 3 years. Market value at first rental ($340,000) becomes cost base. Taxable gain after 50% discount: $27,481.

user_query: I've rented my home for 8 years but there were two vacant periods between tenants (3 months and 2 months). The property was always available for rent during those times. Does the 6-year rule still apply?
